body.p: To His Excellency the Govenor of Kentucky

Your Petitioner Jack Jackson would respectfully represent that he was indicted for Ga betting by the Bourbon Circuit Court at the April Term 1863 1862 and fined at the July Term 1863 by confession of judgment the sum of fifty dollars, the bet was made on the fact of Genl Zollicoffers being killed at the battle of Millspring Your petitioner betting that he was not killed. The bet was a very foolish one on the part of your petitioner for it was made some ^time^ after the battle and at a time when any tolerably well informed man with ought to have had no doubt of the fact. but it was made on a public day in the town of Paris, in the evening, after the warming influence of the genial social enjoyment in after incident to such a day. and under the provocation of considerable disputations argument pro and con. A few days afterwards the bet was cancelled or withdrawn by the parties upon the petitioner paying the winner a pair of boots.
He Respectfully prays your H Excellency to remit said fine.
Jack Jackson this day made oath before me that this petition facts stated in the above petition are true, to the best of his knowledge and belief. This July 23rd 1863.
We concur in the prayer of the within petition, believing the statement within made on oath to be true

R, H, Hanson
Geo. W. Williams
Richd J. Brown
Garrett Davis
B J Pullen
Jno J Hampton
R T Davis
N. B. Rice
John A Prall

Bourbon Cir. Ct
John Jackson Pettn to remit fine
$58. } Betting
Fine Remitted
J F Robinson
Enclosed to R. H. Hanson Eq Paris
Issd July 24 1863
